item.title: Projects and Data Sets
item.description:
What is a Project / Data Set

Within the AMRcloud user can create different projects and data sets.

Project is a structural element of the AMRcloud platform that allows to group several data sets at the user's discretion.

Data set(s) is a basic unit within the project that contains information with which AMRcloud works directly.

How to create a project

In order to create a project, user should press the + New Project button in the upper left corner of the screen after entering the personal account.

The modal dialog “Add new project” invites user to fill in the “New project name” and “Project subtitle” fields (with a limit of 255 characters). It is strongly recommended to use unique or significantly different names for your projects. Do not limit yourself to the “test1” and “test2” variants. The project subtitle can be represented by keywords that explain the name.

Types of projects

User can work with two types of projects:

  • My Project
  • Team Project

My Project is a personal user project. Access to the data is granted to the owner alone. The owner can share his project's data with other users by generating external public links.

Team Project is a project for working with other users in a team. One of the users becomes a team administrator (i.e. creator), and others become team members (i.e. users who invited by the team administrator).

Data sets

Within the project user creates several data sets. To create a new data set, the user needs to open the project by clicking the “Open” button and then click the “+ New Set” button.

The modal dialog “Add New Set” invites user to fill in the “New set name” and “Set subtitle” fields (with a limit of 255 characters). It is strongly recommended to use unique or significantly different names for your sets. Do not limit yourself to the “test1” and “test2” variants. The set subtitle can be represented by keywords that explain the name.

After creating the project and the data set, user can start uploading the data. To do it, the user needs to open the project, to click the left mouse button on the data set and then to click the “Edit Set” button.

item.title: Data preparation
item.description:
The “Golden Rules” for the source data

One of the key points of working with the AMRcloud platform is the structuring of your source data.

The main principles of data organization can be formulated as the following “Golden Rules”:

  1. Each isolate is represented by a separate row in the source datatable.
  2. There are five mandatory columns in the source datatable (Isolate ID, Species Name, Organism Group, Date, AST Data).
  3. There always should be one of the three suffixes after the generic name of antimicrobial drug («_mic», «_dd» or «_sir»).
  4. All other additional columns with metadata in the source datatable are NOT mandatory (geographical data, resistance markers, etc.).

Example Data

The basic requirements for the source data table are listed on the Read Me tab of the data import page. At the bottom of the page there is a link to download an example data table that can be used for the original user's data formatting.

Basic Requirements

To work with the AMRcloud it is necessary to convert the data to a single format.

  1. The data table should be flat. It means that it consists of columns and rows with no additional separators, no hierarchical structures.
  2. The first row of the data table should contain the headings of all columns.
  3. The data table should contain 5 types of mandatory columns:
  • Isolate Identifier (ID_isolate)
  • Organism/Species Name
  • Organism Group
  • Date
  • AST Data

Isolate ID

Non-unique numbers can be used as the isolate ID. The identifier can be either alphabetic or numerical.

Organism/Species Name

For the automatic interpretation Species name must be full. Abbreviations in the species name are not allowed.

Right:

Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pneumoniae

Wrong:

S. aureus, S. pneumoniae

Organism Group

The Organism Group can be shortened, but it should be identical throughout the column.

Right:

Enterobacterales, Staphyl, Enterobacterales, Staphyl (all names are standardized)

Wrong:

Enterobac, Staph, Staphyl, Entbac, Staphylococ (names are not standardized)

Date

The import system will automatically interpret any standard date format. The main condition is the universality of the date format throughout the column.

Right:

12.08.2018, 20.05.2017, 16.03.2014 (unified format DD.MM.YYYY)

Wrong:

13.08.2018, 20/05/19, 03/16/2014 (non-unified format DD.MM.YYYY, DD/MM/YYYY, MM/DD/YYYY)

AST Data

Possible AST data formats:

  • Minimum Inhibitory Concentrations (MICs)
  • Disk Diffusion Inhibition Zone Diameters
  • Susceptibility Categories (S/I/R)

Antimicrobial Suffixes

The header of the column with the results of the antibiotic susceptibility testing must comply with the following rules:

  1. The name of the antimicrobial agent should be full without any reductions, written in English. The list of the legitimate antibiotic names can be downloaded by the link at the bottom of the page.
  2. Every generic ‘Antibiotic’ name shouled be followed by one of the three suffixes with underline symbol:
Minimum Inhibitory Concentrations _mic
Disk Diffusion Inhibition Zone Diameters _dd
Susceptibility Categories _sir

Example:

tobramycin_sir, tetracycline_sir, amoxicillin-clavulanic acid_mic, daptomycin_dd

Note

Antimicrobial agents with special interpretation criterias (user's S/I/R categories) and/or ECOFF criterias can be recorded as follows:

meropenem_ecoff_sir, moxifloxacin_clsi_sir, marbofloxacin_clsi_sir

IMPORTANT!

  • Minimum inhibitory concentration values

    • MIC values are measured in mg/l.
    • Values must be numerical.
    • Non-numerical values containing expressions <= ... or > ... or >= ... would be converted into numerical.
    • Symbols <= and >= standing before the numbers are ignored.
    • Numbers standing after > symbol would be multiplied by 2.

  • Disk Diffusion Inhibition Zone Diameters

    • Diameter values measured in mm.
    • Values could be integers greater than or equal to 6.

  • Susceptibility Categories

    • Allowed values: “S”, “I”, “R”.
    • Every isolate may have only one susceptibility category.

Right:

S, S, R (one susceptibility category for every isolate)

Wrong:

S+I, S+I, I+R (more than one susceptibility category for every isolate)

Additional Columns

Additional Columns — filling in such columns is not mandatory.

  1. Spatial Information
    • geographical objects (city, region, country, etc.)
    • latitude
    • longitude
  2. Metadata (textual data)
  3. Metadata (numerical data)
  4. Resistance Markers (resistance mechanisms, genes or mutations, etc.)

Spatial Information

Geographical objects may include the name of a city, region, country. User can also specify more detailed address (e.g. specific hospital wing). Latitude and Longitude can be changed manually if automatic determination of the objects’ coordinates did not work.

The main requirements and recommendations for the geographical data are presented in the “Step 3: Geocoding” stage.

Metadata (textual data)

User can select a maximum of 10 parameter columns containing textual metadata. For example, “Clinic Material Localisation”, “Hospital department”, etc.

It is recommended to include the column with geographical objects names in here. Individual patient’ characteristics may also be included in here (e.g. “Febrilic Fever” column). Recommended values: “Yes”, “No”, “Not applicable”.

Metadata (numerical data)

User can select only one continuous numeric variable such as “Patient's age”, “weight”, etc.

Resistance Markers

  • Total number of resistance markers is unlimited.
  • User may create his own “group of markers”.
  • Resistance markers may include resistance mechanisms, genes or mutations, and other data that can be correlated with phenotypic resistance data .

The following notation system is recommended:

Investigation of the specific genetic or phenotypic markers... Value(s)
...was conducted with positive test result "OXA-48", "KPC", "MRSA", "CTX-M-15" etc.
...was conducted with negative test result "Negative"
...was **not** conducted "Not defined"
...is not applicable for the microorganism empty cell

item.title: Step 1 - Upload Data
item.description:
Uploading

After inspecting the Read Me tab user can start uploading data into AMRcloud. To do this, go to the Step One tab, press the “Browse…" button and select the file with data for uploading. After successfully uploading the table, you should press the “Validate and Save Step One” button.

IMPORTANT!

  • AMRcloud supports uploading of .xlsx and .csv data tables.
  • User can customize the data table preview with the special slider (displaying from 5 to 30 rows).
  • At the “Options for csv file” panel user can configure the display of the data tables uploaded in .csv format (such tables have no columns — all information is presented as rows).

Text Encoding Problems

If user has problems with text encoding in the uploaded data table, he needs to open the source file with any suitable text editor and re-save it with the UTF-8 encoding. Then the file will need to be re-uploaded into AMRcloud.

item.title: Step 2 - Set Fields
item.description:
At this stage for correct work of all analytical components of the AMRcloud platform user should correctly correlate the names of eight standard system categories with the columns from the uploaded data table.

On the left side of the screen there are standard categories (for example, “Isolate ID”, “Organism Group(s)") with basic information and requirements. On the right side of the screen there are panels with drop-down lists of table column headers, with which the user correlates system categories.

Isolate ID

  • This is a mandatory category.
  • Isolate ID can be any unique identifier that doesn't include special characters (?,!,%$#><)

Organism Group(s)

  • This is a desirable category.
  • Grouping of organisms (species) is useful for analyzing combined prevalence and AST data of several species.
  • Use any name(s) for organism group(s), taxonomic (e.g. Enterobacterales) or non-taxonomic (e.g. Anaerobes, Gramnegative).

Organism/Species Names

  • This is a mandatory category.
  • Use Latinized binomial names acoording to official nomenclature (e.g. Escherichia coli).
  • Proper genus and species names are automatically recognized to apply specific breakpoints and define susceptibility categories.

Right:

Klebsiella pneumoniae, Acinetobacter baumannii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa (no reductions, corresponds to the official nomenclature)

Wrong:

K. pneumoniae, A. baumannii, P. aeruginosa (reductions are used)

After selecting the appropriate column name from the drop-down list, user can press the “Check Species Names” button for automatic checking.

After pressing the “Check Species Names” button a small table will appear with the names that fails the verification process (i.e. the names of microorganisms which were not recognized by the system). Then user should look through this table carefully:

  • If there are errors in some names (for example, a missing letter), user should correct the errors right in the editor window by double-clicking the necessary cell with the left mouse button and pressing the “Correct species names” button.
  • If there are no spelling errors, it means that there are no microorganisms with such names in the system. Such microorganisms are not excluded from the general data — analysis charts will also be built for them — only they will be colored not according to susceptibility categories, but in a solid gray color. If user works with his own S/I/R susceptibility categories, there will be no problem in identifying microorganism species.

If interpretation criteria for particular microorganism species have not been found, the system will try to apply criteria for the appropriate microorganism group.

Example. If Salmonella typhi criterias are not found, then Salmonella spp. criterias would be applied.

Date

  • This is a mandatory category.
  • Records without a date or with a varying date format will not be imported.

If all the dates are arranged correctly and uniformly, user (after selecting the corresponding header from the drop-down list) will see the time scale “Date Range Privew”. If the date format is not recognized with the Auto option, user should try to select one of the alternative formats:

  • 2018-12-31 (i.e. year-month-day)
  • 2018-31-12 (i.e. year-day-month)
  • 31-12-2018 (i.e. day-month-year)
  • 12-31-2018 (i.e. month-day-year)
Once user has selected the date format, he should check the box “Check if you see the time scale?".

Spatial Information

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • There are two types of spatial information: “Geolocation” and “Longitude/Latitude Coordinates”.

Geolocations can include regions, such as countries and states, natural areas, cities and smaller locality types. The system will attempt to identify geolocations and find respective geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) automatically. Optionally, user can check the box and select the columns containg the Longitude and Latitude values.

Please note that only the first 10 rows of the corresponding column are displayed to the user for preview.

Numeric Parameter

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • As a numeric parameter, user can upload one of any continuous numeric variable, for example Age, Weight, etc.

User should check the corresponding box on the right side of the screen and select the table header form the drop-down list.

Please note that only the first 10 rows of the corresponding column are displayed to the user for preview.

Resistance Markers

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • The total number of columns of this type is unlimited.

If there are column(s) containing information about Resistance Markers (resistance mechanisms, genes or mutations) that can be correlated with phenotypic resistance data, check the box and then select the respective column(s). Column header(s) will be used as name(s) of the Marker Groups.

Additional Parameters

  • This is not a mandatory category.
  • A maximum of 10 Parameter Columns can be selected.
  • Column titles will be used as names of the parameters.
  • Drag selected parameters to set their priority from 1 to 10.

Completing Step Two

To go to the next stage of the data import user should press the “Validate Step Two” button. It is recommended to review and double-check all the points of the current stage before saving.

item.title: Step 3 - Geocode
item.description:
Geocoding is an important step in creating a basis with which AMRcloud builds various maps and pins geographic markers.

Regions, cities and even separate hospital departments can be used as geographical objects in AMRcloud.

General Information

In order to start the geocoding process you should press the “1.Geocode it” button. This process takes some time, so user should wait for the system to put coordinates in the table below and for markers to appear in the map preview window.

In order to open the map preview, user should press the header of the “Map: preview” blue panel.

After the user is sure that all markers with coordinates are placed correctly, he should press the “Validate Step Three” button and proceed to the next import stage.

If Location(s) Is Not Found

If AMRcloud didn't recognize the geographical object (didn't put coordinates next to its name), user should check the correctness of the name of the geographical object. If there are errors in the name(s), it is necessary to correct the data in the source data table, to reset all import steps, and to upload the newly corrected version.

If there are no errors in the names of geographical objects, user should manually set the coordinates. To do it he should enter the corresponding coordinates in the right table (orange panel “Location(s) not found”) and press the button “Fix Coordinates”.

How to Get the Coordinates

User can get the coordinates of the required geographical objects using the preview map.

. To do it, user should zoom in on a geographical object and click on it with the left mouse button. The object's Latitude and Longtitude will be displayed below the map. After determining the object's coordinates, user should copy and paste them into the corresponding fields. . If user doesn't know the exact location of the geographical object on the map, he can use search string on the map and then left-click the object. .

Incorrect Marker's Position

The AMRcloud system may not automatically recognize user's geographical objects. For example, instead of St. Petersburg, Russia, system may pin St. Petersburg, Florida, USA. Therefore, user should carefully check the preview map before saving the results of the geocoding stage.

If user wants to correct the position of the marker on the map, he should:

  1. Click with the left mouse button on the required cell in the green table.
  2. Press the “Edit Coordinates” button.
  3. Edit the coordinates in the orange table.
  4. Press the “Fix Coordinates” button.

Local Objects

If user often works with his specific set of local geographical objects, he can save the coordinates of these local objects for future automatic use. For this purpose after editing coordinates in orange table, user should check the box “Save coordinates for future usage”. So the geographical coordinates will be permanently assigned to the corresponding name of the geographical object and will be saved in the user account. At subsequent downloads, the coordinates of objects with the same names will be automatically geocoded.

item.title: Step 4 - Determine S/I/R
item.description: First of all, at this stage user should choose the interpretation criteria from the drop-down list and press the “Interpret MIC and Disk Diffusion data” button. After the table with the interpretation statuses appears below, user can press the button “Complete All Steps” and finish the data import process.
